name: Purdue Model
description: The Purdue Enterprise Reference Architecture (PERA) is a widely-adopted framework for securing Industrial Control Systems (ICS) and Operational Technology (OT) networks. It defines hierarchical zones with strict communication boundaries to protect critical industrial processes from cyber threats.

Level_0.name: Physical Process
Level_0.description: Physical devices that directly interface with the industrial process: sensors, actuators, PLCs, RTUs, field instruments, drives, valves, pumps

Level_1.name: Basic Control
Level_1.description: Control systems that manage the physical process: SCADA systems, DCS, historians, HMIs that directly control field devices

Level_2.name: Supervisory Control
Level_2.description: Supervisory and monitoring systems: engineering workstations, supervisory HMIs, batch management, recipe management

Level_3.name: Operations Management
Level_3.description: Manufacturing operations and production management: MES, LIMS, maintenance systems, production scheduling, asset management

Level_4.name: Enterprise Network
Level_4.description: Corporate IT systems: ERP, email, file servers, Active Directory, business intelligence, corporate databases

DMZ.name: Demilitarized Zone
DMZ.description: Buffer zone between OT and IT networks: data historians accessible to IT, remote access gateways, patch management servers

allowed_communications.rationale: Field devices must communicate with control systems
Control systems must send data to supervisory systems
Supervisory systems must interface with MES/operations
Operations systems must integrate with enterprise IT
Historians can replicate data to DMZ for IT access
IT can access OT data via DMZ

prohibited_communications.rationale: Field devices must not communicate directly with operations systems - violates zone isolation
Field devices must NEVER communicate with enterprise IT - critical security violation
Control systems must not communicate directly with enterprise IT - use DMZ
Enterprise IT must NEVER have direct access to field devices
Enterprise IT must not have direct access to control systems - use DMZ

required_enforcement_points.rationale: Protect field devices from unauthorized control commands
Protect control systems from supervisory layer threats
Critical boundary between OT supervisory and operations - MUST have deep packet inspection
Critical boundary between OT and IT - MUST have stateful inspection and IDS/IPS
One-way communication preferred to prevent IT-to-OT attacks
